verses.text: Therefore, be imitators of God, as beloved children.
verses.comment: This verse calls believers to model their lives after God, reflecting His holiness. See also Jesus' teaching in Matthew 5:48 on being 'perfect as your heavenly Father is perfect.'

verses.text: And walk in love, just as Christ loved us and gave Himself for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God for a pleasing aroma.
verses.comment: Paul draws a parallel with Old Testament sacrifices (Leviticus 2:9). Christ's self-offering fulfills the highest form of sacrificial love. The phrase 'pleasing aroma' is used in temple language, connecting Jesus' sacrifice to liturgical traditions.

verses.text: But sexual immorality and all impurity or greed must not even be named among you, as is proper for saints.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes purity and sets a high standard for Christian conduct; these sins are completely incompatible with the identity of saints, who are set apart for God.

verses.text: Also, there must be no filthiness, foolish talk, or coarse jokes—these are not fitting—but rather thanksgiving.
verses.comment: Holiness is reflected not only in actions, but also speech. Paul redirects believers to thanksgiving, echoing a focus on continual prayer and gratitude in Christian tradition.

verses.text: For you can be sure of this: that everyone who is sexually immoral or impure, or who is greedy (that is, an idolater), has no inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.
verses.comment: Greed is called 'idolatry' here, showing that it replaces God. The 'kingdom of Christ and of God' puts Jesus on equal footing with God the Father—another affirmation of Christ’s divinity.

verses.text: Let no one deceive you with empty words, for because of these things, the wrath of God comes upon the sons of disobedience.
verses.comment: Paul warns against false teachings and watered-down morality. The term 'sons of disobedience' marks a distinct contrast between the church and the world.

verses.text: Therefore, do not be partners with them.
verses.comment: This echoes Psalm 1, urging believers to avoid close association with the wicked. Christian life involves separation from sin.

verses.text: For at one time you were darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of light.
verses.comment: Christians are fundamentally changed; 'light in the Lord' refers to the new creation in Christ, recalling John 1:4-5.

verses.text: For the fruit of the light consists in all goodness and righteousness and truth.
verses.comment: Paul uses 'fruit' language, reminiscent of the fruit of the Spirit in Galatians 5. True faith must evidence itself in virtuous actions.

verses.text: And try to learn what is pleasing to the Lord.
verses.comment: Spiritual growth involves discernment, not just rules, seeking what God loves. This points to a life shaped by continual renewal.

verses.text: Do not take part in the unfruitful works of darkness, but instead, expose them.
verses.comment: Christians are to witness to the world by confronting sin, not merely avoiding it. This affirms a prophetic role for the community.

verses.text: For it is shameful even to mention what they do in secret.
verses.comment: Paul calls attention to the depth of corruption outside the faith. Silence on these matters at times preserves holiness.

verses.text: But everything exposed by the light becomes visible, for what makes everything visible is light.
verses.comment: Light here symbolizes Christ and truth. The church, as Christ’s body, brings darkness into the open for healing and conversion.

verses.text: Therefore it says: 'Awake, you who sleep, and arise from the dead, and Christ will shine on you.'
verses.comment: This may be a primitive Christian hymn, echoing Isaiah 60:1. The imagery refers to spiritual resurrection—typifying baptism, when a person is raised to new life in Christ.

verses.text: Look carefully, then, at how you walk—not as unwise but as wise,
verses.comment: Paul repeatedly urges reflection on one’s lifestyle. Wisdom is central in both Testaments as the means to walk in God’s will.

verses.text: Redeeming the time, because the days are evil.
verses.comment: 'Redeeming the time' means making the most of every opportunity since the world is corrupt. There is urgency in Paul’s instructions to live intentionally and purposefully.

verses.text: Therefore, do not be foolish, but understand what the Lord’s will is.
verses.comment: Obedience requires not just rule-keeping but internal knowledge and conformity to God’s desires, reminiscent of the psalmist’s longing to understand God’s law.

verses.text: And do not get drunk with wine, for that is debauchery, but be filled with the Spirit,
verses.comment: Drunkenness is to be rejected; instead, believers are called to experience the true joy and transforming presence of the Holy Spirit, as seen at Pentecost.

verses.text: Speaking to one another with psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody to the Lord with all your heart,
verses.comment: Early Christian worship is liturgical—centered on communal singing of psalms, hymns, and songs. This verse underscores corporate worship as formative for faith.

verses.text: Giving thanks always and for everything to God the Father in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ,
verses.comment: Gratitude is a perpetual mark of Christian life. Prayers and thanksgiving are always directed to the Father, through Christ, reflecting the mediation of Jesus.

verses.text: Submitting to one another out of reverence for Christ.
verses.comment: Mutual submission is rooted in Christ’s example of humility (Philippians 2). This is the foundation for Christian relationships—requiring humility and sacrificial love.

verses.text: Wives, submit to your own husbands as to the Lord.
verses.comment: Submission here is not servility but part of the ordered harmony Paul calls for in Christian households, rooted in devotion to Christ.

verses.text: For the husband is the head of the wife, even as Christ is the head of the church—He Himself the Savior of the body.
verses.comment: Paul grounds familial order in Christ’s relationship to the church. This analogy has been interpreted as supporting headship and sacrificial service.

verses.text: But as the church submits to Christ, so also wives should submit to their husbands in everything.
verses.comment: The church’s submission to Christ is the model for marriage, signifying trust and unity. This typology is spiritual as well as practical.

verses.text: Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave Himself up for her.
verses.comment: Husbands’ love is sacrificial, imitating Christ’s love for the church. The giving up of self recalls both the Cross and the sacrificial system.

verses.text: That He might sanctify her, cleansing her by the washing of water with the word,
verses.comment: This points to the sacramental washing of baptism, in which Christ sanctifies the church. The connection of water and the word emphasizes both ritual and proclamation.

verses.text: So that He might present the church to Himself in splendor, without stain or wrinkle or any such thing, but holy and blameless.
verses.comment: Paul describes the church’s ultimate destiny as Christ’s pure and glorious bride. This language draws on both Old Testament covenant imagery and eschatological hope.

verses.text: In the same way, husbands ought to love their wives as their own bodies. He who loves his wife loves himself.
verses.comment: The union of husband and wife is described in terms drawn from the creation account, amplifying the dignity and unity of marriage.

verses.text: For no one ever hated his own flesh, but he nourishes and cares for it, just as Christ does for the church,
verses.comment: Paul likens marital love to Christ’s care for the church. This stresses the self-giving and nurturing aspect of both relationships.

verses.text: For we are members of His body.
verses.comment: Believers are not just Christ’s followers but, mystically, share in His very body. This has implications for church unity, discipline, and identity.

verses.text: ‘For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife, and the two shall become one flesh.’
verses.comment: Paul quotes Genesis 2:24, showing the consistency of his teaching with the Torah. Christ unites Himself to the church just as husband and wife are one flesh—demonstrating unity and sacramental mystery.

verses.text: This mystery is profound, but I am saying it with reference to Christ and the church.
verses.comment: The term 'mystery' denotes a reality now fully revealed in Christ: the union of Christ and the church is prefigured by marriage, and this mystery is at the heart of the Christian faith and worship.

verses.text: Nevertheless, each one of you should love his wife as himself, and the wife must respect her husband.
verses.comment: The great mystery of Christ and the church is reflected in marriage through mutual love and respect. Married life is called to reflect this supernatural bond and order, pointing ultimately to the reality of Christ’s union with His people.
